events.originalText: The first spate of violence between Muslims and Christians began in Jos, Nigeria, and would end in more than 200 deaths.
events.subtitle: 2010 Jos riots
events.headline: Violence erupts in Jos, Nigeria, resulting in over 200 deaths

events.originalText: Mount Nyiragongo, a volcano in the Democratic Republic of the Congo, began an eruption that killed hundreds and left about 120,000 people homeless in the nearby town of Goma.
events.subtitle: Mount Nyiragongo
events.headline: Mount Nyiragongo eruption kills hundreds in Goma, DRC

events.originalText: In Little Saigon, California, a series of protests began when the owner of a video rental store displayed an image of Ho Chi Minh.
events.subtitle: Little Saigon, Orange County
events.headline: Protests in Little Saigon over Ho Chi Minh image

events.originalText: The Drudge Report became the first news source to break the Clinton–Lewinsky scandal to the public.
events.subtitle: Drudge Report
events.headline: Drudge Report breaks Clinton–Lewinsky scandal

events.originalText: Patrick Purdy opened fire in an elementary school in Stockton, California, killing 5 and wounding 32 others.
events.subtitle: 1989 Stockton schoolyard shooting
events.headline: Stockton school shooting leaves 5 dead, 32 wounded

events.originalText: A U.S. Air Force B-52 Stratofortress collided with a KC-135 Stratotanker during aerial refueling over the Mediterranean Sea, dropping three hydrogen bombs on land near Palomares, Spain, and a fourth one into the sea.
events.subtitle: Boeing B-52 Stratofortress
events.headline: B-52 collision drops hydrogen bombs near Palomares, Spain

events.originalText: Patrice Lumumba (pictured), a former prime minister of Congo-Léopoldville, was murdered in circumstances suggesting the support and complicity of the Belgian and US governments.
events.subtitle: Patrice Lumumba
events.headline: Patrice Lumumba murdered with Belgian and US involvement

events.originalText: Three days before leaving office, U.S. president Dwight D. Eisenhower delivered a farewell speech to the nation, in which he warned about the dangers of the military–industrial complex.
events.subtitle: Dwight D. Eisenhower
events.headline: Eisenhower warns of military–industrial complex in farewell speech

events.originalText: Indonesian National Revolution: The Renville Agreement between the Netherlands and Indonesian republicans was ratified, in an ultimately unsuccessful attempt to resolve disputes arising from the Linggadjati Agreement of 1946.
events.subtitle: Indonesian National Revolution
events.headline: Renville Agreement ratified in Indonesian National Revolution

events.originalText: Swedish diplomat Raoul Wallenberg, who had saved thousands of Jews from the Holocaust, was taken into Soviet custody during the Siege of Budapest and was never seen in public again.
events.subtitle: Raoul Wallenberg
events.headline: Raoul Wallenberg taken into Soviet custody during Siege of Budapest

events.originalText: World War II: Australian troops advanced along the northern part of Bougainville Island (in present-day Papua New Guinea) and began fighting Japanese forces in the Battle of Tsimba Ridge.
events.subtitle: World War II
events.headline: Australian troops battle Japanese forces in Bougainville Island

events.originalText: The Volstead Act went into effect, beginning the prohibition of alcohol in the United States.
events.subtitle: Volstead Act
events.headline: Volstead Act initiates prohibition in the United States

events.originalText: Robert Falcon Scott's ill-fated Terra Nova Expedition reached the South Pole, only to find that Roald Amundsen's team had beaten them by 33 days.
events.subtitle: Robert Falcon Scott
events.headline: Scott's Terra Nova Expedition reaches South Pole after Amundsen

events.originalText: Lorrin A. Thurston and the Citizens' Committee of Public Safety led the overthrow of the Hawaiian Kingdom and the government of Queen Liliʻuokalani (pictured).
events.subtitle: Lorrin A. Thurston
events.headline: Overthrow of Hawaiian Kingdom led by Lorrin A. Thurston

events.originalText: On James Cook's second voyage, his vessel HMS Resolution became the first vessel to cross the Antarctic Circle.
events.subtitle: James Cook
events.headline: HMS Resolution crosses Antarctic Circle on Cook's voyage

events.originalText: Representatives of Catherine de' Medici, the regent of France, drew up the Edict of Saint-Germain, providing limited tolerance to the Protestant Huguenots.
events.subtitle: Catherine de' Medici
events.headline: Edict of Saint-Germain provides tolerance to Huguenots

events.originalText: Gregory XI, the last Avignon pope, entered Rome after a four-month journey from Avignon, returning the papacy to its original city.
events.subtitle: Pope Gregory XI
events.headline: Gregory XI returns papacy to Rome from Avignon
